It's been said before, it needs to be said again. This is not Dungeon Keeper. It is not close to Dungeon Keeper. It will not fill the void in your heart left by Dungeon Keeper.

My biggest gripe: trying to set up an economy using this system requires a tedious amount of micro-management: You need enemy heroes to be able to easily get to your loot, then intercept them before they easily get away with it. By definition, this means you need to change something about your set-up on the fly, for every hero, in real time.

A slog that misses everything about what made the genre fun.

reviewText:
I don't think I have ever been this depressed by a game before. As the spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper, I had very high hopes for this game. It is, saddly, terrible. Everything that made the previous game unique and interesting (monsters moving into and interacting with your dungeon, converting enemies to your cause, waging war against the forces of good,) have all been stripped away.

Yes, you can place monsters in your dungeon and have them protect narrow areas, but they don't roam the area, they don't interact with your dungen, and there are very few types available. The troll/blacksmiths are gone, and so are their traps, doors, and other gadgets to make the dungeon interesting. The prisons remain, but the Mistresses are gone so enemies can't be converted. The only reason you even capture them is to get soul energy out of them.

You no longer wage war. Yes, you can fight heroes, and your mosnters will too. However, you can no longer send your monsters after heroes, they will only engage if the hero happens to stumble into them. Of course, you wouldn't want to send monsters after heroes aanymore either, since they need to survive to be fattened up with soul energy.

It is like they tooke the most basic features of Dungeon Keeper, kept those, and threw away everything that gave the game character. Now, you must run about taking care of every little task using your avatar, with no help from the decorative monsters. Basically, this has become FarmVille with a slightly darker background and sub-par voice acting.

reviewText:
Remember Dungean Keeper? This is a lot like that, but with a better premise (IMHO). So you're an evil overlord. But rather than wanting to keep adventurers out of you dungeon, you WANT them to come in, get their jollies, have the time of their life, then capture them and suck all the joy out of their souls.

That's a gross simplification, but that's the basic idea. This is sort of like a TD game, in that you have invaders coming into your place and you need to direct them to where you want them to go. But instead of trying to kill them quickly, you essentially want to kill them slowly. You need to give them a good fight, let them find some treasure, maybe even get them laid (not really, but that would be totally expected in this game). THEN you want to imprison them and suck all that contented adventurous soul out of their well-satisfied bodies.

Very fun, very much in keeping with the tradition established by Dungeon Keeper and Overlord.

I give it a B+

reviewText: Oh goodness, I can't say enough about thi game. I have lamented the death of Dungeon Keeper 3 for years, and finally it has been reborn in a modern form with new gameplay mechanics. The idea of harvesting soul energy from heroes you have pampered and 'built up', only to tear them down and lock them away is deliciously evil. Managing a dungeon in this manner can be difficult, (it's YOUR gold in those piles....so you end up running out fairly quickly if heroes take alot of it.) there's a good deal of micro management involved, as well as planning, room building, etc. All to tease those heroes with lovely jewels, books, equipment, and more, so you can suck all of that out of them when they fall. The soul energy collected goes to prestiege items which make your dungeon more impressive, and boost your power. So it's a bit of a roundabout buildup until you can build more prisons and have enough prestiege to easily deal with the invading heroes, and even champions. Lots of good stuff here!

8/10 in my books.

reviewText:
If you're looking for Dungeon Keeper, keep looking. This game is essentially a theme park for people trying to kill you. Sure, you run a dungeon. Sure, there's a dungeon heart. Sure, there's goblins, and libraries and armories and monsters... but the library and armory is just something to make heroes happier, and your gold is mostly used to pile on the floor to keep heroes interested, all so that you can kill them before they decide to leave your amusement park and leave with the real currency of the game: soul energy.

Honestly, it sucks. It's a decent enough game in its own right; not nearly worth the price or anyone's attention, but it should be shot for pretending to cater to the Dungeon Keeper crowd.

That said, I guess it's okay if you pretend DK doesn't exist and this wasn't made to copy that much better series. I still don't recommend it for purchase, unless it's going for a few pennies and you feel like wasting money.

reviewText:
I won't complain that this game isn't Dungeon Keeper. No matter how much I really want it to be War For The Overworld.

This game is, however, more like what would happen if someone decided to try and mix Dota 2 and Dungeon Keeper.
You have a physical pressence in the game you have to manually direct to attack, activate things and generally progress.
While games like Baldurs Gate may spring to mind. this does not have much in the way of combat other than 'go attack that person... right, they died...'. There is no customisation of your 'keeper' further than leveling up to gain spells with real-time cool-downs...
This might be better likened to Overlord, but without the cusomisation of your weapons... or the thrilling gameplay.

I don't like games that have me watching for seconds, checking my mana, waiting for a specific moment between the slow, repeating combat animations and then unleashing some spell that i'm going to have to wait another 00:40 to use again. This is not Warcraft!

The game quickly gets pissy and overly picky about what you need to do. The dynamic of 'let heroes in and let them get real happy to farm their souls' comes off as a little strange at best. Let them walk in, slay your creatures, then plunder the convenient piles of gold lay around?
oh... kaay?
kill them on their way out so you don't lose the gold and do gain their souls.
Right?
Ok, let's do that while trying to dig out some more rooms of your dungeon, expand your area of influence with pentagrams that summon enemies and need population points to build and build some decorations to give yourself prestiege. Don't forget to complete the challenges on each level to level up your guy to get better combat spells and that... did I forget to mention if you take too long, the next b*gger comes in and starts plundering somewhere else? Oh, and you're being attacked by someone else on the other side of your dungeon, better get back there. Better still, teleport somewhere even further away if you want to get there faster!
uuh... no!

There is too much fiddly, useless and over-complicated systems.
I can't compare this to dungeon keeper. that would be an insult to both games.
This has multiple 'currencies' to constantly keep an eye on as you're building. Lacking tutorials that leave you not entirely sure what you're supposed to be doing and, I hate to be mean, but if you're playing a game about managing a dungeon, i don't need to tell myself to walk over here so the hero doesn't see me before i kill him... honestly, it does not seem very well thought out.

I would love to change my review, but this is too under-developed to be an MMO, far too far away from being simple enough to play casually and, to be frank, no fun.

reviewText:
Takes the role-reversal irony of dungeon keeper to it's logical extreme.  Unfortunately.

Your goal is to design a dungeon that is 'fun' enough and rewarding enough to satisfy adventurers - so that you can harvest their happiness.

It's too puzzley to feel like a satisfying strategy game, and to 'fuzzy' to be a working puzzle.  Adventurers move around in a semi-random manner, and most levels have so many already dug out paths that you can't effectively funnel them.

You're also penalized if adventurers die to your monsters and traps.  Instead you have to run over to them personally and deliver the killing blow.  This and other mechanics lead to an incredibly annoying amount of micromanagement.

It sucks.  Don't buy it, even on sale.
